Lesson: It is preferable to use a numbering system that has enough capacity to evolve with the need for additional body points as the system is utilized and operated. This system needs to be carefully described early in a program life cycle. Users of the system must exercise discipline to –stick with” this system, even when the expedient path might tempt them to do otherwise.
Categories: Launch Systems, Ground processing and manifesting, Engineering design and project processes and standards,

Title: Acquisition Philosophy and Mechanism
Abstract: A “Fly-off” type of procurement using a relatively small Source Evaluation Board (SEB) can minimize the time to assess, award, and implement a contract. However, in order to minimize the Government's risk under this process, the SEB must leverage enough expertise (in “ex-official” status, if necessary, to fill any knowledge gaps the small SEB might have) to ensure all the Contractor's business practices are adequate and reflect a system that provides sufficient insight/oversight to build the required “hands-off” Government/Contractor relationship after contract award.
Lesson:
In order to use a “fly-off” type of procurement to minimize the time to assess, award, and implement a contract while ensuring the Government's risk is minimized, the following issues should be considered.  
     

      
        While it can improve efficiency, a small selection team (SEB) may not be adequately effective in assessing all technical and programmatic areas.  

        Any technical or programmatic areas not sufficiently addressed during procurement may increase the Government's risk during contract implementation. This is especially true in instances where an originally selected system design is found to be inadequate and in need of a re-design (in the case of the Project in question, new analytical tools and techniques available after Contract award helped to identify new risks and needed design improvements). While the Government is responsible to identify inadequacies at any and all times during the project life cycle, it must make every effort to completely remove itself from the Contractor's design process. Any participation by the Government in the design undermines the philosophy of placing the risk (via ownership of design) on the Contractor and exposes the Government to a higher level of risk. The Government must be cognizant of this immigration of risk when it elects to participate in a design process, and must balance the risk
      of effectively acquiring ownership of the design against other risks inherent in the situation or migrating to it.  

        Since the procurement's goal is to minimize the time from start to finish, part of it its philosophy is to instill efficiency into the Contractor-Government roles and relationships. Thus, it becomes paramount during the selection process to ensure that the Contractor's processes, procedures, and tools are adequate (as based on some established criteria such as ISO 9001 and/or CMMI) to allow the Government to take a “hands-off” approach during implementation. Also, any criteria to be used to verify/validate and or assess the Contractor's work after contract award must be consistent and compatible with the performance criteria levied on the Contractor.  
      
    The Project successfully addressed these issues with the addition of extra resources (technical experts, analysis tools, schedule, and funding) and the willingness to accept additional development risk via more hands-on involvement in order to reduce the overall risk. In addition, the Project planned its recovery efforts such that they where focused on the product and did not overburden its delivery with force fit or unnecessary processes, i.e. only those processes critical to the products success were developed and employed rather than imposing a conventional process certification/assessment approach. Thus, the Project's approach to compliment the SEB's fly-off approach with real-time adjustments (even against conventional wisdom and/or original intent) based on the increased knowledge that contract implementation brings ensured that the best interests of the Agency where secured.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Plasma Arcs from Pyro Firing May Cause Prolonged NSI Shorts (2003)
Abstract: NSI firing circuit design has not previously taken into account the high probability of plasma shorts and subsequent hard-shorting, as seen during testing on MER, which allowed ground (chassis) return current during pyrotechnic events. Mars Exploration Rover experience has shown that molten NSI fragments can cause a prolonged NSI pin-to-case short that can damage flight hardware. Thirteen design, analysis, inspection, and test recommendations in the areas of Parts Selection and Reliability Analysis, Power/Pyro Design, and System Grounding are offered to account for this possibility.
Lesson: Plasma arcs from NSI firing can cause a permanent internal pin-to-case short circuit as low as ~ 0 ohms due to deposition of NSI fragments. This failure mechanism can produce current levels that may damage flight hardware, and the likelihood of its occurring appears to be increased by: Firing the NSI into a mechanical actuation device with a small “free” volume. High bus voltage system level firing circuit (32.8 V on MER). Firing multiple NSI's within one device. (Conductive gas can flow from one NSI to another within same device.) Long firing pulse duration (e.g., 32 ms on MER).
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: In-Flight Passivation of Lithium-Based Spacecraft Batteries (2003)
Abstract: A testbed incident affecting the Mars Exploration Rover (MER) flight computer alerted JPL to the consequences of a failure to consider passivation effects on the rover's lithium primary batteries. A passivation-induced voltage transient during a mission critical event could cause PORs, leading to corrupted memory, repeated reboots, and possible loss of mission. Characterize and plan for battery passivation and its effects, and consider designing spacecraft circuitry to tolerate such effects.
Lesson: Assume that a dormant lithium chemistry spacecraft battery will develop a passivation layer and that the effects on the spacecraft circuitry may be significant: Lithium-based spacecraft batteries should be characterized and depassivation measures planned, as required A standard Department of Defense practice is to characterize and depassivate each spacecraft battery lot-- both on the ground and in flight.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Termination & Transition
Abstract: The termination phase of a Project's life cycle whether it is implemented early or as scheduled, requires appropriate planning to ensure the Agency's investments (intellectual and real properties) and resources developed during the Project's run are preserved, communicated and returned for Agency benefit. Therefore, it is critical that a termination plan is developed and supported with adequate resources.
Lesson:
Projects should have a termination plan in place to ensure that the Agency's investment is maximized. This is critical in cases where termination is premature (cases where a Project is ended prior to running its entire planned life-cycle). In particular, the following should be considered and included in the termination plan:  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        
      
    a. The amount of resources required to secure, document, and disseminate critical Project information (Lessons Learned, technical, administrative and management achievements)  
    b. The integration of Project personnel and other resources into appropriate Center activities once they are released from their Project assignments  
     c. The partnering, dependencies, and legal issues with respect to termination of the Project's agreements with other entities  
    d. Re-activation strategies and plans, should the Project or a closely related activity take up the Project's requirements in the future
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Management: Styles and Tools for Success
Abstract: The success of a project is greatly impacted by the management style of the Project Manager and the manner in which each phase of the Project's life cycle is implemented.
Lesson:
The Project Manager applied many techniques and best practices to the Project including:  
     

      
        Ensuring the efforts, findings, and resources of an investigative board dealing with the failure of a similar system feed into the manufacturing/construction phase of this project.  

        Challenging the project team. The team was challenged to develop a composite based structure that did not have any predecessors. The team took pride and ownership in their innovation.  

        Empowering the project team with the authority to act within their area.  

        Welcoming new staff and bringing them up to speed quickly. The PM mentored or paired up seasoned personnel with new comers to help them acclimatize to the Project.  

        Taking responsibility for things that went wrong and giving credit for things that went right. This owning of responsibility permeated through out the team based on the PM's example and leadership.  

        Integrating everyone into the Project regardless of their experience or technical background. Project members felt they were an integral part of the Project and played a key role in its success. This atmosphere ensured that Project members maintained their enthusiasm and high participation level.  

        Listening and considering each team member's input during meetings and other discussions. The PM created an environment of mutual respect whereby team members respected but debated each other's input and ultimately accepted and supported the group's consensus (sometimes dictated by the PM).  

        Openly communicating his own experience/knowledge gaps to the team. This honesty and openness contributed to the Project's feelings that they were all part of a team and all necessary for its success.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Marketing Project Contributions, Successes and Research Results to Customers and Management (Knowledge Management)
Abstract: The success of a project is greatly impacted by the visibility and advocacy within the NASA community.
Lesson: Lack of project promotion to upper management and inadequate or slow communication of project results can result in an inaccurate appraisal of a project's value to its customers. High visibility and timely communication increase a project's opportunities for recognition and gaining/maintaining support. Low visibility and slow communication may increase a project's vulnerability to budget cuts, milestone de-scoping and a perception that the research results are unimportant or too incremental to merit continued support.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Management: Training and Development of Project Managers
Abstract: The training and development of new or inexperienced Project Managers (PM) can be greatly enhanced by pairing them with a Deputy Project Manager (DPM) that is experienced in at least one system wide area (programmatic or technical) such that there is a balance between the management team's applied and academic experience.
Lesson:
The paring of a seasoned engineer with a minimally experienced PM that recently completed formal management training, created a well-rounded management team for the Project. A seasoned engineer will have extensive knowledge of the engineering processes and an understanding of the challenges unique to the existing Center environment. The newly trained PM will have knowledge and experience with the most current management tools. However, in order for this combination to work, both the PM and DPM must be sensitive and supportive of the other's strengths and weaknesses. All of these factors made for a high-quality working environment.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        The lack of prior management experience can be addressed by incorporating various tools and techniques such as software based risk management, schedules, and knowledge management. In addition the use of SMEs and frequent, but informal meetings helps to fill out any experience gaps remaining in the Project.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Knowledge Management: Collecting, Archiving, and Disseminating Project Results/Information
Abstract: Ensuring that a Project's collective wisdom is collected, archived, and disseminated depends on including a schedule, budget, and process for their accomplishment in the Project plan.
Lesson: If the tasks of collecting, archiving, and disseminating critical Project results/information are not included in the Project plan they will not be accomplished adequately. This is especially true for Projects that are terminated prematurely since this usually results in a relatively quick scattering of Project resources. In addition, people tend to focus on their new tasks and find it difficult to reflect on those of the past.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Resources Management: Construction-of-Facilities (CofF) Projects Under Full Cost Accounting (FCA)
Abstract: Funding sources under FCA for CofF projects aimed at building or improving unique test facilities must include specific customers in addition to Agency General and Administrative (G&A).
Lesson: In the Agency's FCA mode CofF projects, especially those aimed at building or improving test facilities can no longer depend exclusively on Agency G&A sources for funding. Rather, funding must be acquired through the projects or activities that will explicitly benefit from their results. Therefore, these funding sources must be identified and acquired during early Project formulation.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Management: Construction of Facilities Project Pitfalls
Abstract: The success of a project is greatly impacted by the visibility and advocacy within the NASA community, stakeholders, customers, and end users. In addition, an ambiguous project scope can lead to well-meaning changes on behalf of the project team which impact the cost, resources, and schedule to such an extent that the completion of the project may no longer be justified. For projects which cannot be clearly defined from the outset, clear communication between the Project Manager (PM) and the project sponsor is critical in order to receive continued support by the Agency.
Lesson:
The following represents key factors and contributors to the Project's cancellation:  
     

      
        The dependence on funding from Agency institutional budgets, coupled with end users that historically did not pay for the facilities maintenance or infrastructure, did not provide the Project with sufficient resources to operate under full-cost accounting. Once the Agency converted to the FCA system, the Project's “non-paying” end users did not have the funds to sustain the Project and their advocacy became ineffective.  

        The lack of project promotion to upper management and inadequate or slow communication of project results to stakeholders can result in an inaccurate appraisal of a project's value. This may increase a project's vulnerability to budget cuts, milestone de-scoping and a perception that the research results are unimportant or too incremental to merit continued support.  

        The lack of a comprehensively defined and controlled project scope can result in significant requirements creep and/or excessive modifications. This is especially true when various stakeholders have conflicting requirements. This will make it difficult if not impossible for the Project to estimate and control its budget.  

        The lack of a clear stakeholder hierarchy made it difficult to prioritize their requests and to control the project scope. So while the project was approved by the funding organization with a specific schedule and budget it, continued to accept input from other sources and was no longer able to stay within the approved budget and schedule.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Management: Effective Project Management Training
Abstract: A successful Project Management (PM) Training and Development (T&D) program requires training activities which are compatible with the Center's culture and focuses on topics immediately applicable to people's work and provided in an environment that promotes interactive “hands-on” learning.
Lesson: In order to create an effective PM T&D Program attention must be given to both the training content and learning environment. The training content that worked best for the Center's PM community had several characteristics including: local relevance and application, narrow focus, minimal history and theory, and in-class “hands-on” work supported by experienced and credible instructors. The key was to provide training that the students felt confident in and could apply immediately to their work. The factors that contributed the most to the student's training environment addressed issues such as the student's schedule, travel requirements, in-class comfort, attention span, and visual and audio stimulation. The key was to provide a training experience that fostered student participation.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Project Manager Training and Development Program
Abstract: Building a successful Project Management Training and Development Program in a Center dominated by scientists and engineers having cultural indifference to Project Management.
Lesson:
Creative approaches can be used to overcome cultural barriers to and resource limitations on a PMT&D program. Some specific methods used included:  
      

    <ol type="a">
        Building a mutually beneficial relationship with the Academy of Program and Project Leadership (APPL) and establishing ARC as “APPL West” helped bring more courses to ARC and reduced the financial and schedule burden to ARC for training courses.  

        Volunteering ARC to pilot new training and development ideas from APPL provided APPL with valuable feedback and ARC with additional training opportunities and input into the kinds of training resources the Agency would fund.  

        Forming personal relationships helped find personnel within ARC who had an interest in and need for PM training and development. By initially targeting training to this group, the dominant culture of indifference to PM development was circumvented.  
        
      

    <ol start="2">
        Establishing credibility for providing interesting, relevant and valuable training and development classes has led to continued and increased interest in PM training and development. Several tactics used to accomplish this were:  
      

    <ol type="a">
        Using person to person contact to solicit information on training needs to determine what types of training should be offered. There is an emphasis on offering training that is closely tied to people's current jobs and has immediate applicability. Learning is emphasized rather than certification.  

        Matching training opportunities with members of the community. Specific classes are actively marketed to appropriate personnel through phone calls and targeted email. Course applications are reviewed for appropriateness to ensure personnel will benefit from participation.  

        Continually monitoring courses for usefulness and applicability to the ARC environment. Feedback is collected from participants through course evaluations, phone calls and email. Additionally, having the PMT&D coordinator observe classes in person helps confirm the evaluations through conversations with participants. The feedback is provided to APPL.  

        Emphasizing and offering “hands on” training whenever possible.  

        Bringing interesting and knowledgeable guest speakers to the Center as another method of providing training. Location and amenities (such as providing refreshments) are considered in making training opportunities attractive.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Scaffolding Buildup to Include Human Factors Review
Abstract: Scaffolding for payload access is built in support of the mission instead of the task, which can often result in awkward postures and excessive reaches.
Lesson: Scaffolding build up should require a human factors review in addition to safety to ensure personnel can safely perform the task.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Considerations for Lifting Hardware (without identified lift points)
Abstract: The Lifting with an overhead crane of unique and off center of gravity hardware requires review and consideration of lifting method to ensure a level and safe lift.
Lesson: If the IEA inner ring has no lifting point, it would better to lift about the center of gravity of the ring. This can be accomplished by using one web strap shackled to itself around the apex (or wrapped around the apex so that both ends can be brought together at the top), with the second one looped through that loop and each end attached to the crane hook.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Use of ErgoMasterTM software
Abstract: The use of ErgoMasterTM software requires precise photos of operation being analyzed in order to attain accurate results.
Lesson: In order to fully utilize the ErgoMaster software and attain accurate and viable results it is necessary to become highly familiar with the task being assessed prior to the actual operation.

Title: Comet Nucleus Tour (CONTOUR) Mishap Investigation
Abstract: The Comet Nucleus Tour, CONTOUR, was designed and built by Johns Hopkins University with specialized support from NASA as a part of NASA's Discovery series of solar system exploration satellites. Launched on July 3, 2002, it was intended to encounter at least two comets to perform a variety of analyses on comet material. However, sometime after the solid rocket motor (SRM) intended to move the satellite out of eccentric earth orbit was fired, the satellite was lost. Mission design did not allow for observation or telemetry coverage during SRM burn, so the mishap investigation board was unable to determine with certainty the cause of the failure. However, a major finding of the investigation was that telemetry or visual coverage of the satellite during SRM burn was, in fact, possible and may help prevent similar mishaps in the future.
Lesson:
I. A major lesson learned was that all spacecraft should retain telemetry or visual contact during critical phases of the mission.  
      
    II. The team felt the mishap may have been driven by certain practices that the team described as more typical of small projects managed by contractor Principal Investigators. These practices include:  
    II-1. Reliance of CONTOUR project on analysis by similarity  
    Although flight history of a selected component is one aspect of acceptance by similarity, it is important to consider whether the application is consistent and within the bounds of previous qualification.  
     II-2. Inadequate systems engineering process and specification of requirements  
    The board cited the fact that few requirements were imposed by NASA regarding the way contractors document or performed work on CONTOUR, creating opportunities for contractors to adopt nonstandard engineering practices.  
     II-3. Inadequate review functions  
    The board felt that inadequate oversight was especially dangerous in combination with nonstandard engineering practices.  
      
     Other observations noted by the team were the lack of telemetry/observation of spacecraft during a critical mission event, a tendency to rely on subcontractors without appropriate insight/oversight, the use of analytic models that were not specific to CONTOUR, a limited understanding of SRM plume heating environments in space, the lack of an orbital debris conjunction plan, and a limited understanding of SRM operating conditions. These are covered in detail in the "CONTOUR Mishap Investigation Board Report.”
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Chemical Overexposure During Thermal Vacuum Cleaning
Abstract: Evening and night shift personnel were required to vacuum and wipe the internal surfaces of three thermal vacuum chambers with Isopropyl Alcohol (IPA). A technician completed the two smaller facilities (3-foot diameter by 3-foot deep) and was in the process of surface wiping with IPA the third chamber (7-foot diameter by 8-foot deep horizontal chamber), when the shift leader found the technician unconscious in the chamber (with feet facing the opening). The shift leader pulled him out of the chamber. It was noted that the employee was breathing but unconscious and the supervisor contacted 911. The technician regained consciousness and fully recovered without medical treatment.
Lesson:
Employees and supervisors must consider that commonly used laboratory chemicals such as IPA can be a health hazard if inhaled in unsafe quantities by multiple short term exposures without sufficient recovery time, or used with insufficient ventilation.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        Supervisors and employees must recognize that even simple operations such as cleaning must be evaluated for potential hazards prior to the start of the operation.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Autoclave Purge Blower Failure
Abstract: A mishap occurred in a large (18' X 20') autoclave resulting in damage to government property of approximately $23K. The mishap was likely the result of a small amount of accumulated debris around a pneumatic valve, coupled with a minor error in pressure system logic, which failed to alert operators of the event prior to failure.
Lesson:
Pressure systems may operate safely for years until a specific set of conditions occur and a mishap results. Pneumatic systems should be installed in a way that takes maximum advantage of available logic controls. Check valves and additional external controls should also be incorporated to minimize the potential for back flow into pressure vessels.  
      
     Finally, even a relatively minor amount of accumulated debris due to age, shop conditions, or other environmental factors can result in mishap.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Complex Procedures Used To Perform Payload Testing
Lesson: Minimize the number of deviations to procedures by mitigating payload developer issues prior to delivery and testing at KSC.

Title: Design and Operational Control Considerations for Steam Systems
Abstract: Systemic management and technical failures led to the catastrophic rupture of a test system. 3 lessons are published regarding this specific incident; this lesson addresses unique considerations for steam-based systems.
Lesson: Steam-based systems have unique issues that must be considered in their design, operation, and maintenance.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Detection of Steam Pipe Wall Thinning Due to Corrosion
Abstract: Systemic management and technical failures led to the catastrophic rupture of a test system. 3 lessons are published regarding this specific incident; this lesson addresses problems with the detection of pipe wall thinning due to corrosion and the selection of inadequate test methods.
Lesson: Methods of evaluating critical system parameters must be verified as sufficiently reliable to support risk assessment
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Lock out/Tag out Procedure Not Followed
Abstract: A mechanical technician came into contact with an energized electrical circuit at the LC-39, Pad A Oxidizer Storage Area. A control cabinet had been removed and the circuit breaker feeding the bare conductors had been locked out in the electrical switchboard. Another contractor was modifying the electrical distribution system. The LOTO device was improperly removed and the circuit was later re-energized.
Lesson:
Hazardous situations can be created if LOTO devices are improperly removed.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        During construction, it is critical to understand the proper placement of LOTO devices.  

        Hazardous situations can be created if bare conductors are not properly secured.  

        During electrical system modification, it is critical to involve all affected users.  

        After electrical system modification, it is critical for affected users to revalidate their systems.

Title: Transporting Tools for Overhead Work
Abstract: Overhead work requires special precautions and safe behavior practices to ensure that equipment does not fall on personnel and equipment underneath.
Lesson: Use safe procedures in accordance with behavior-based safety principles when transporting and operating tools during overhead work.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Ground Network (GN) Ka-band Ground Terminal - Design, Integration, and Test Issues
Abstract: Throughout the requirements development, design, implementation, integration and testing activities for this ground terminal, there were a number of events and/or circumstances that caused lessons to be learned. These events and lessons are listed below.
Lesson:
a. System Requirements Document (SRD)  
    In addition to Ka-band requirements, the SRD also included S band transmit and receive requirements for the system since the antenna was dual band. However, S band requirements should have been stated at a higher level. Much effort went into justifying and verifying S band equipment performance specs. Nearly 75% of the SRD requirements were related to S band. The SRD should have focused less on the S band requirements, since the intent of the system was primarily to demonstrate the Ka performance. The S band subsystems utilized standard, proven equipment that were already in use in the GN.  
      
    b. High Data Rate Receiver  
     For bit error rate (BER) testing, it is recommended to use receivers that have been optimized for the data rates under test. Although the unit used during demonstration testing was very flexible and useful for general lab support, the receiver performance in terms of implementation loss at the higher data rates of interest was not adequate to support the objectives of the test. The implementation loss of the test receiver was higher than expected and created difficulties in obtaining useful BER test data. It would also be recommended that a receiver manufacturer take into account the system channel magnitude and phase response to optimally match the receiver filter for best ISI performance.  
      
    c. Boresite Antenna  
     The use of a smaller boresite antenna, or separate antennas for S and Ka band would provide better performance during boresite testing, particularly in high wind situations. For example, a WR-34 horn was used during the latter portion of the demonstration testing, and it provided improved performance compared to the one meter parabolic antenna for this test scenario. It is also recommended to use the same boresite antenna for on-site testing that is used for factory testing. When problems were encountered on-site that did not appear at the factory, the local boresite antenna was blamed for the problems. Using the same boresite antenna would eliminate any finger pointing in a similar situation.  
      
    d. Channel Distortions  
    It is recommended that system requirements be levied on one vender that is responsible for the entire ground terminal design, integration, and test. For example, the magnitude and phase response for the entire channel should be specified from RF input to IF output, and the vendor should perform an allocation of theses end-to-end system requirements to individual components. Distortion measurements through the whole system should be verified at the factory prior to delivery. Also it is recommended that the receiver be mounted close to antenna, and transfer the IF signal in digital format via fiber optic cable rather than at the intermediate frequency. Cable runs should be minimized, and the use very low loss cable is recommended.  
      
    e. Radome  
    The vendor should demonstrate water tightness of radome prior to delivery and installation on-site.  
      
    f. Antenna axis configuration  
    The X-Y axis configuration is the recommended approach for a ground terminal that is required to track low-earth orbiting spacecraft. This configuration precludes the use of a third tilt axis to handle high elevation passes. The X-Y axis system is less complex, improving maintenance and reliability.  
      
    g. Ka Feed components  
    Nearly all problems encountered with the feed were the result of low quality cables and adapters. Recommend in the future that reliability be considered more than cost for the feed subsystem components.

Title: Space Network (SN) Ka-band Infrastructure - Design, Integration, and Test Issues
Abstract: A Ka-band return infrastructure was implemented for NASA's Space Network under the GSFC Ka-Band Transition Project (KaTP). Throughout the requirements development, design, implementation, and testing activities for this ground terminal, there were a number of events or circumstances that caused lessons to be learned. These events and lesson learned are listed below.
Lesson:
System Requirements Document (SRD) Development  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        
      
    The SRD development task unnecessarily grew in scope and began to encompass future follow-on work. In addition to Ka-band IF requirements, several versions of the SRD included performance issues related to CCSDS data routing. Considerable time and effort was expended on reviewing documentation that was not pertinent to the task at hand. The SRD should have focused on the function and performance requirements of the Ka-band IF implementation task   

    <ol start="2">
        Analysis  
      
    The WSC KaTP team did not originally allocate any labor costs or schedule impacts associated with performing analysis to the waveguide and phase nonlinearity issues. Delays to the KaTP project were incurred while a contractor team was called on to perform additional “impact to system performance” analysis. An example of this was experienced during the decision on total amounts of phase nonlinearity allowable for the KaTP infrastructure during the Waveguide Equalizer procurement. On a project with the scope, complexity and challenges of the KaTP, the team must consider budgeting additional hours for these unforeseen problems.  

    <ol start="3">
        Vendor Delivery  
      
    While the KaTP implementation schedule was aggressive, one could not account for the large delays encountered from the vendors. The contractor team spent considerable time and energy working with the vendor and pushing for delivery. In future large procurements, the contractor team should account for some vendor delays when forecasting schedule and there should be some way of enforcing vendors to deliver hardware on time (either through incentives or penalties incorporated into the contract). The procurement office should have been involved earlier and they may have worked the delivery issues since they control the payments and have more clout with the vendor. Additional time in schedule should be allocated to do more work on vendor surveys and “requests for information” from prospective vendors. This may have given the KaTP team a better feel for aggressive specifications and alternative architectures. In some cases the team received one vendor quote, which implies
    the specifications may have been too restrictive.  

    <ol start="4">
        Equipment Procurement  
      
    The KaTP contractor team has learned to project more time into a schedule to account for RFP technical evaluations, initiating procurements through the CLF, and getting vendors under contract. For large acquisitions, this process can take four to eight weeks.  

    <ol start="5">
        Project Budget  
      
    The size and complexity of the KaTP presented several unique challenges. From the onset, NASA project management stated the project had limited funds, however, they wanted to accomplish all of the goals of the project. The KaTP team attempted to achieve a system that met all the requirements with a minimal amount of risk to the project budget and schedule. This approach drove the team to implement an architecture similar to the legacy design and in the future the team should evaluate the critical parameters that impact system performance and choose an architecture that would minimize this risk.   

    <ol start="6">
        Waveguide Equalizer Equipment Definition  
      
    The KaTP team focused on an IF frequency Waveguide Equalizer too quickly without weighing other options. This decision was based somewhat on the legacy equipment design using an IF-based equalizer. The team should have explored other possibilities concurrently but the time and effort was not allocated into the schedule.   

    <ol start="7">
        225 MHz Downconverter Modifications  
      
    The legacy 225 MHz downconverters were built as custom units and the implementation varied from chassis to chassis. This problem could not have been foreseen, a realistic schedule should allot additional time to handle unforeseen problems.  

    <ol start="8">
        Interference with TDRSS Telemetry Signal  
      
    The KaTP team should have contacted the NASA spacecraft engineering group charged with the development of the TDRS- HIJ series spacecraft to determine the rationale for their frequency plan. The spacecraft manufacturer chose to design a specific frequency plan for the TDRS-HIJ series satellites that was not compatible with the SNIP frequency plan. The KaTP team should have researched this issue more thoroughly during the design and implementation of the ground infrastructure.  

    <ol start="9">
        SN Demonstration  
      
    The KaTP was hindered during the SN Demonstration tests by test equipment that exhibited higher than expected implementation losses. A considerable amount of time was spent verifying the test equipment, understanding and characterizing the losses inherent in the various test configurations. It is recommended that test receivers should be optimized for the data rate under test. Future testing should incorporate test equipment that meets or exceeds the fidelity one is trying to demonstrate. Suspect test equipment reduces the confidence in the test results and impacts the schedule and budget.

Title: Accident Investigations/Transition Process from NASA-led to Independent Board-led Investigation
Abstract: To avoid team leadership and public image concerns, NASA should recognize that it will not be the lead public investigative entity in a human space flight mishap.
Lesson: NASA should recognize from the beginning that NASA will not be the lead public investigative entity of a manned spaceflight mishap.

Title: Accident Investigations/Information Technology (IT) Capabilities and Planning
Abstract: More IT pre-planning would have enabled a quicker and smoother start-up of the investigation.
Lesson: While the IT personnel did an outstanding job in a short period of time, more IT pre-planning would have caused the startup of the investigation to be quicker and smoother.

Title: Accident Investigations/Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel (ASAP)/National Transportation and Safety Board (NTSB) Roles in Investigation
Abstract: The roles that organizations such as NASA's Aerospace Safety Advisory Panel and National Transportation Safety Board will play in an accident should be clearly established in advance.
Lesson: Organizations, such NASA's ASAP, and the National Transportation and Safety Board (NTSB) should be either held to their charter or provided some advisory role in investigations.

Title: Accident Investigations/Contingency Action Plan/Personnel Planning
Abstract: Because of the need for rapid staff up, NASA should identify in advance basic personnel requirements for support to the NASA Task Force.
Lesson: Basic personnel requirements for support to the NASA Task Force should be identified ahead of time at each NASA center.

Title: Accident Investigations/Minutes Taking Support to Board
Abstract: The hiring of safety and mission assurance/engineering personnel, not skilled in minutes taking, to support the Investigation Board provided unsatisfactory results. Subsequent hiring of skilled minutes-takers resolved the problem.
Lesson: To support the minutes taking requirements of an accident investigation board in a professional manner, the hiring of non-skilled personnel to do this task is totally unacceptable.

Title: Accident Investigations/Contingency Action Plan(s)/Supporting Organizations
Abstract: NASA needs to understand that a human space flight accident field recovery operation will involve many organizations at various levels of Government.
Lesson: A manned space flight accident will involve many national, state, local/regional emergency organizations in many phases of the investigation, especially debris recovery.

Title: Accident Investigations/Procurement of Goods and Services
Abstract: Even though NASA may be able to provide goods and services more effectively and economically, an investigation board may use outside contractors to ensure a perception of "independence."
Lesson: In general, an independent accident investigation board may use outside contractors on the basis of “independence” even if that function can be provided more effectively by the NASA center or another government agency.

Title: Accident Investigations/Investigation Organizer (IO)/IO Utilization for Major Mishap Investigations
Abstract: The "Investigation Organizer" management and modeling tool was the primary investigation management tool for the Columbia accident investigation; however, acceptance of the tool was not consistent across investigative groups because some investigators considered it a developmental tool rather than an operational tool.
Lesson: Although Investigation Organizer was the primary investigation management tool for the Columbia accident investigation, it was not initially utilized across all investigative groups within the CAIB. It had been previously used on only one other investigation, the loss of the CONTOUR spacecraft. Acceptance of the tool was not consistent across groups. Some investigators complained that the Board was being forced to use a developmental tool in an operational environment.

Title: Accident Investigations/Document Management and Tracking
Abstract: Electronic and hard copy documents submitted to the Accident Investigation Board should be numbered with unique page numbers to facilitate document integrity and traceability of hard copies to their electronic versions.
Lesson: Since the electronic and hard copy documents submitted by CTF to the CAIB were not numbered, document management staff were required to electronically endorse all electronic files, and hand number label all hard copy files for PBMA and CAIB generated documents. This resulted in duplicate documents being unnecessarily entered into the CAIB Document Database.

Title: Accident Investigations/Formulation of an E-mail Retention and Archival Policy for an Independent Investigation
Abstract: There is a need for an independent Accident Investigation Board to establish and adopt a formal policy for use, retention, and archiving of investigation-related e-mail to minimize inadvertent transmittal and archiving of sensitive data.
Lesson:
During the investigation, the Board did not adopt a formal policy for use, retention, and archiving of investigation e-mail. Consequently, e-mail was used to transmit CAIB generated investigative materials and analysis. Approximately two months after the investigation began, the General Counsel and DOJ/Aspen began researching NASA and NARA e-mail retention and archival policies for guidance.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        E-mail generated by CAIB members may be subject to NASA e-mail and document retention policies because the applications and data reside on the JSC network

Title: Accident Investigations/Independent Server/Local Area Network (LAN) for Investigation Support
Abstract: Late establishment of an independent database server for use by the Accident Investigation Board prevented maximum utilization of the data storage and searching features by board members and investigators.
Lesson:
The independent CAIB Database Server provided a resource for storing documents and databases containing privileged and sensitive data.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        Investigators stored CAIB documents under shared and personal folders on the Server. This permitted data to be backed up and stored off-site for disaster recovery purposes, and allowed users to share files without relying upon JSC e-mail.  

        As a result of the server not being deployed until six weeks into the investigation, CAIB members and investigators did not utilize the data storage and searching features of the CAIB Database Server to the maximum extent possible.

Title: Accident Investigations/Software Tool Selection
Abstract: A set of prioritized requirements should be considered in the decision process for selecting an accident investigation software tool, or tools, to meet the varying needs of users.
Lesson: Different levels of software functionality are required by members of the investigation board and support staff (e.g., top-level board members vs. library support staff). A thorough review of software alternatives based on a clear set of functional requirements should precede selection of a tool. Criteria, such as having a single user interface, ease of use, remote access, security, etc., should be prioritized and considered in the decision-making process to select a tool, or set of tools, to meet the needs of the users.

Title: Accident Investigations/Web-based Mishap Investigation Support System (MISS) Hardware and Software Infrastructure
Abstract: To reduce service outages, a Mishap Investigation Support System hardware and software infrastructure fully tested and ready to support a full range of perceived and anticipated operational needs is required.
Lesson:
As a result of problems encountered, lessons were learned quickly and changes implemented just as quickly. Only limited time was available for system testing and under only limited conditions. The systems engineering life-cycle was compressed into a virtual real-time requirements analysis/design/test/implementation.  
      
    Lessons include the need for traditional multi-functional, end-to-end testing of all system components over the full range of operational scenarios, including different internet routing and NASA firewall configurations. Again the need exists to have a system ready to support the full range of perceived and anticipated operational needs based on the CAIB experience (see #1).

Title: Accident Investigations/Information Technology (IT) Support Requirements for Major Mishap Investigation
Abstract: An in-place, operational web-based Mishap Investigation Support System on hot standby, and a designated management team ready to support operational requirements and customization are needed to support accident investigation/information technology requirements for a major mishap.
Lesson:
Real-time, crisis-mode systems engineering can never capture all potential future requirements. You do the best that you can and make the best decisions you can with the information you have at the time.  
      
    The overarching lesson learned is that NASA needs to have a web-based, Mishap Investigation Support System (MISS) in-place and operational, "locked and loaded" on hot standby to support major mishaps. The system must fulfill the requirement set identified in the next section. It is equally important to have a designated (hot standby) management team ready to support the myriad of operational requirements and customization needs that one can expect to emerge.  
      
    In the final analysis, the experienced PBMA management team provided the necessary support to implement the dynamically evolving CAIB requirements.

Title: Accident Investigations/Investigator Tool Kit/Digital Cameras
Abstract: A supply of both digital and film cameras should be immediately available by NASA to the Investigation Board.
Lesson: For accident investigations, an initial supply of both digital and film cameras should be made available to the Board immediately by the NASA centers photo laboratory or imagery department.

Title: Accident Investigations/Public Affairs Functions
Abstract: Respective roles of Investigation Board and NASA Public Affairs representatives should be agreed to, and PAO's should work more closely to ensure releases and responses to Congressional inquiries do not catch each other off guard.
Lesson: Roles of respective public affairs representatives would run smoother if their respective charters were agreed to in the Contingency Action Plan and the representatives were either co-located or in closer contact.

Title: Accident Investigations/Archiving of Data & Library Requirements
Abstract: All data and documentation should be handled with the understanding that it will ultimately be archived.
Lesson: For accident investigations, handle all data and documentation with the understanding that it will eventually be officially archived.

Title: Accident Investigations/Facilities Management
Abstract: A list of potential facilities for Investigation Board use should be maintained to facilitate investigation start-up.
Lesson: A list of available facilities should be maintained by all NASA centers to facilitate accident investigation board and Task Force startup.

Title: Accident Investigations/Office Equipment
Abstract: Standard office electronics should be immediately available to the Investigation Board or Task Force without waiting for them to be requested to avoid contractual nightmares caused by hastily arranged contracts.
Lesson: Do not wait for the accident investigation board or Task Force to ask for standard office electronics (B&W/Color printers and copiers, fax machines, TV's with VCR and DVD/CD, CD Burners, etc.).

Title: Accident Investigations/Configuration Management of Data
Abstract: Strong support to the CM organization is required to develop a fully functional action/request process and as quickly as possible and minimize the impact to the conduct of the investigation.
Lesson: To develop a fully functioning action/request for information process to support an accident investigation will take several weeks. Assure strong support to the CM organization because until it is working, the investigation will be hampered.

Title: Accident Investigations/Action Request System
Abstract: Complex Action/Request for Information Forms require numerous iterations to implement cross-organizationally and may cause the authorization process to break down.
Lesson: Complex forms will take endless iterations to implement evenly across all organizations and may cause the action authorization process to break down.

Title: Accident Investigations/Database/Collaborative Tool PBMA (Process Based Mission Assurance)
Abstract: Experience with PBMA indicates that a single configuration management/electronic library will not meet needs of all investigation participants.
Lesson: Do not assume that a single CM/electronic library tool will meet needs of all investigation participants.

Title: Accident Investigations/Investigator Tool Kit/Tape Recorders
Abstract: To avoid members from being required to purchase their own tape recorders for field witness interviews, as initially was the case for the Columbia accident, an initial supply of digital and tape recorders should be made immediately available to the Investigation Board.
Lesson: An initial supply of both digital and tape recorders should be made available to an accident investigation board immediately by the NASA center's contingency operations department.

Title: Accident Investigations/Public Hearings
Abstract: To avoid witness scheduling and pre-hearing preparation legal complications, a specific individual on the Investigation Board staff should propose and coordinate witnesses for public hearings.
Lesson: An accident investigation board should assign a specific individual on the Board staff to propose and coordinate witness for the Public Hearings.

Title: Accident Investigations/Recorders
Abstract: Ground rules, methods, and equipment for witness interview transcription, review, and revision should be established up front to preclude subsequent issues.
Lesson: For accident investigations, ground rules, processes and equipment necessary for review and revision of transcribed interviews should be established prior to the first interview.

Title: Accident Investigations/Facilities Management/Telephone & Video Conferencing Capability
Abstract: To ensure more efficient organization of critical telephone and video conferencing capabilities, a conference specialist should be part of the IT start-up team.
Lesson: A conferencing specialist should be included as part of the Information Technology (IT) startup team.

Title: Accident Investigations/Database/Collaborative Tool PBMA (Process Based Mission Assurance)
Abstract: Unfamiliar database tools cause delays and use of multiple systems cause additional delay and tax the IT support staff.
Lesson: Database tools that most people are unfamiliar with will cause delays in initiating investigation. Multiple systems, implemented to satisfy specific needs, cause additional startup delay and tax the time of IT support staff.

Title: Accident Investigations/Security Clearance Transfers
Abstract: Inefficiencies were created because some personnel did not have necessary security clearances for conduction of the investigation.
Lesson: Proper security clearances are necessary for key personnel conducting accident investigations.

Title: Accident Investigations/Action Request System
Abstract: Data needs to be delivered in familiar, commonly-used formats compatible with IT/CM tools to avoid unnecessary administrative effort to archive.
Lesson: Strive for well-known, commonly used formats in all data deliveries to an accident investigation board.

Title: Accident Investigations/Information Technology and Database Security
Abstract: Different software tools with differing access protocols caused inefficiencies. Electronic investigation tools should have secure, automated, user-friendly access.
Lesson: Electronic tools used for accident investigations should have a secure, automated, user-friendly access system.

Title: Accident Investigations/Database/Collaborative Tool PBMA (Process Based Mission Assurance)
Abstract: Experience with PBMA indicates that it was oversold and it did not deliver expected capabilities. It is unlikely, however, that a software system for action item tracking and investigative data configuration management can be selected that will be wholly satisfactory to the entire board.
Lesson: For large accident investigation support, is unlikely that you can select a software system for action item tracking and configuration management of investigative data that will make everyone happy at the same time.

Title: Accident Investigations/Information Technology (IT) Capabilities and Planning/Personnel
Abstract: Difficulty in contacting the IT support person and getting issues resolved, necessitates in situ, resident IT specialists, at least for investigation start-up activities.
Lesson: At least during startup, the resident IT specialists need to be in situ with the Board and with the Task Force and support available 24/7.

Title: Accident Investigations/Department of Justice/Roles in Investigation
Abstract: The Department of Justice played a critical role in archiving accident investigation data, interview statements, and interface with the National Archives and Records Administration; however, its role was not established until the second month of the investigation. The role should be codified in advance.
Lesson: The Civil Division of the Department of Justice represents the Government in a wide variety of large civil litigation, including contract claims cases, frauds, aviation/admiralty torts cases, challenges to government programs, patents, environmental, and toxic tort claims, as well as other areas. The Office of Litigation Support (OLS) provides automated litigation support services to Civil Division attorneys in support of these cases, including support for document production and discovery, creation of large databases of evidentiary documents, and pretrial and trial support. DOJ played a critical role of archiving both Challenger and Columbia accident investigation data, interview statements, and interface with the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA).

Title: Accident Investigations/Contingency Action Plan/Personnel Planning
Abstract: A basic set of minimum organizational support requirements for the NASA Task Force should be identified ahead of time at each NASA Center.
Lesson: Identify basic organizational support requirements for the NASA Task Force ahead of time at each NASA Center.

Title: Accident Investigations/Background Information
Abstract: Because some investigation board members may have minimal knowledge of space flight systems, NASA needs to anticipate this and be better prepared with technical and procedural materials to increase the board members learning curve.
Lesson: NASA needs to be better prepared to handle the independent investigators in terms of technical and procedural materials that will increase the learning curve of Board members.

Title: Accident Investigations/Alignment with NASA Investigative Working Groups
Abstract: Reorganization of an independent investigation board or supporting NASA investigation structure in mid-stream as was required in the case of the Columbia accident is destabilizing and should be avoided when possible.
Lesson: Re-organizing an independent investigation board or NASA investigation structures in mid-stream is inherently destabilizing and should be avoided as much as possible.

Title: Accident Investigations/Investigation Organizer (IO)/IO Standard and Ad Hoc Report Capability
Abstract: A combination of factors, including lack of time by investigators to search through "Investigation Organizer" links on a personal computer and the tool's lack of a logic tree report capability severely limited its use.
Lesson: Investigation Organizer (IO) was touted supporting the CAIB's engineering/management investigation logic tree. It was believed that the extensive linking of data gathered across the groups would prevent “stove piping” of data and allow investigators to cross-reference information in support of their findings and recommendations. A combination of factors, including lack of time by investigators to search through the IO links on a personal computer and IO's lack of logic tree report capability, severely limited use of the system by other than personnel keying in IO data.

Title: Accident Investigations/Off-site Storage of Investigative Data and Evidence
Abstract: A small appliance fire at the Investigation Board's facility pointed to the need for a process to duplicate and secure unique electronic data at an off-site facility to provide disaster recovery protection.
Lesson:
At the beginning of the investigation, unique electronic data such as interview and public hearing tapes were not duplicated and stored off-site. Mid-way through the investigation, document management staff began duplicating this media and delivering it to a secure off-site storage facility. This process provided disaster recovery protection that had not previously existed.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        A backup of data stored by the investigators on JSC and personal computers was left to the individuals to perform on diskettes and CDs. These backups, if performed at all, were typically stored on-site in close proximity to user desktops. Consequently, if the fire had caused severe damage to the facility, this data may have been lost forever.

Title: Accident Investigations/Public Inputs to the Investigation/Utilization of a Public Website & Toll-Free Number
Abstract: The Accident Investigation Board received valuable submissions from the public--both average citizens and experts--through its public website and 800 number and should be considered for all future large accident investigations.
Lesson:
Future public investigations should not hesitate to seek information from the public. There will be many valuable submissions from not only the average person, but also from many former experts who wish to contact the Board.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        A complete submission response plan is required to utilize appropriately the valuable information that might come in. This would include  
      
    a. The ability to evaluate, prioritize, and categorize multiple submissions.  
    b. Single place for various formats-letters, web, fax, email to be stored in a common record format.  
    c. Single individual with full knowledge of the areas of investigation, the subject matter, and history of submissions to make sound judgments on disposition of submissions.  
    d. A second independent review of all submissions for correct disposition.  
    e. A collaborative environment for subject matter experts or investigators to transfer, evaluate and act upon submissions.  

      
        The use of public submissions and follow-up by investigators is dependent on the commitment of the investigation leaders to review submissions in a timely manner and treat them as an important source of information. This must be conveyed to the investigating team.  

        Policy decisions should be made early in an investigation to determine to what extent all public submissions, in whatever form, should be responded to; either personally, or by automatic reply.  

        The Public Database should be web-based and secure.  

        It is important to make progress in reviewing submissions daily in order not to fall behind in review.  
      
    a. If there are functions to be tailored, created, or developed, find a mechanism to review and evaluate actions in parallel with development.  
    b. Excel is valuable decision tools to keep the momentum in reviewing submissions- make sure the database elements can be downloaded to Excel.  

      
        It would be helpful if the reviewer of actions has access to the latest thinking and activities of each group. This would have precluded a number of actions for the groups to work on due to the activity already being under consideration.  

        Responses to the actions were not consistent within each group. It is important to set an early framework for the expectations and degree of response to each action. For example- some closed actions without comments, others detailed at least a reason why the action was closed.

Title: Accident Investigations/Document Management, Retention, and Archival Policy for an Independent Investigation
Abstract: The lack of early adoption of a document management and archival policy made it difficult for the document management staff to obtain Investigation Board generated documents for inclusion in the database server.
Lesson:
Early in the investigation, the Board did not adopt a document management and archival policy. Consequently, it was difficult for document management staff to obtain CAIB generated documents from the investigators and members of the Board.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        Investigators considered document management, archiving, and designating documents for release to the public as analogous processes. This made it considerably difficult for the document management staff to obtain documents from investigators for inclusion into the CAIB Database Server.

Title: Accident Investigations/Software Tool Selection
Abstract: A criteria-based software tool selection process should have been implemented. Advanced software tools with which most people are unfamiliar delay investigation initiation.
Lesson: A criteria-based tool selection process should have been implemented, and it should have been kept in mind that advanced software tools that most people are unfamiliar with, such as databases, cause delays in initiating an investigation. Further, the use of multiple software tools implemented to satisfy specific needs cause additional startup delays and tax the IT support staff.

Title: Accident Investigations/Software Tool Selection
Abstract: Difficulties with the single software tool selected to support the Columbia accident investigation point to a need for a functional requirements analysis by a team experienced in the IT requirements of a large-scale mishap investigation prior to tool selection.
Lesson: A functional requirements analysis should be performed prior to software tool selection, and this analysis needs to be performed by a team of people experienced in the IT requirements of a large-scale mishap investigation. In addition, clear IT security requirements need to be identified in advance of tool selection to ensure appropriate safeguarding of sensitive data.

Title: Accident Investigations/Information Technology (IT) Security Constraints and Policy Governing IT system support to Major Mishap Investigations.
Abstract: Clear IT security policies, consistent across all NASA Centers, need to be in place for care and management of ITAR, export control, and investigation sensitive information to avoid complications, cost, and delay.
Lesson: It is critical that NASA has in-place, clear and consistent IT security policies across all NASA centers as it relates to the care and management of ITAR, export control and investigation sensitive information.

Title: Accident Investigations/Transition Process/Integration Functions
Abstract: As evidenced by the fact that the Columbia Task Force was often required to be a major integration function between CAIB investigation teams, an independent accident investigation board may require NASA help integrating itself.
Lesson: An Independent Accident Board is composed of many diverse members and may not be capable of integrating itself without help from NASA.

Title: Prevent Ground Straps from Contacting Power Sources (2002)
Abstract: Two safety incidents occurred during Mars Exploration Rover integration and test, caused by uninsulated, braided traveling ground straps that came into contact with exposed facility power terminals during movement of connected flight hardware. Electrical shorts resulted, causing visible sparks and partial melting of the ground straps and power connectors. All traveling ground straps should be insulated to prevent harm to personnel or critical equipment.
Lesson: Long, un-insulated, copper cables used as traveling ground straps may inadvertently come into contact with facility power sources and harm personnel or critical equipment.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Shipping Container Susceptibility to ESD Charging (2002)
Abstract: Moving and opening a shipping container induced a charge on the surfaces of the container and onto the attached Mars Exploration Rover equipment module. Even with standard ESD control procedures in place, moving and opening a storage container can unexpectedly induce a charge on flight hardware within it. Five recommendations involve ESD training, ESD inspections, and container characterization, approval, and labeling.
Lesson: Even with standard ESD control procedures in place, moving and opening a storage container can unexpectedly induce a charge on flight hardware within it.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: Kennedy Space Center (KSC) Projects and Resources Online (KPRO) Software Development and Implementation
Abstract: Kennedy Space Center (KSC) Projects and Resources Online (KPRO) is a KSC software development project to implement a project management information system that meets the unique requirements of NASA. The KPRO team has encountered both good and bad experiences throughout the software development life cycle. These experiences include: Working in direct consultation with commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) vendors; having a signed agreement when interfacing with external databases; training the target workforce thoroughly for using the developed software; having a management agreement for resources committed to the project; and expending effort to build a cohesive team with proper skills and expertise. These are documented as lessons learned, along with recommendations, and presented as reference for future software development project teams.
Lesson:
Advantages to KPRO were the direct consultation with Microsoft, participation on the P10 (Microsoft Project 2002) Beta Team, and being a member of the Microsoft Joint Development Program. This gave KSC the ability to counter consult with Microsoft and deliver the initial product earlier than the normal life cycle.  

      <li style="list-style: none">  
        

        A signed agreement should be in place before proceeding with implementation of an interface with another database management system. KPRO had a verbal agreement with a NASA counterpart to support an interface between KPRO and a contractor database to provide actual expense data. The KPRO developer proceeded with coding as agreed to verbally. When the verbal agreement was presented in a written format in the form of a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), the decision was made not to provide the verbally agreed-upon interface. Another method was selected. The developer was required to get an account on the contractor reporting system and develop a report rather than receiving the data electronically per a verbal agreement. It is suspected that the reason for the reversal was that upper management was not informed early-on of the terms of the verbal agreement. The new direction resulted in approximately 4 weeks lost time in implementing a requirement to obtain actual expense data
      for projects in KPRO.  

        The project management workforce should be thoroughly trained and engaged in implementing Agency project management processes before introducing a new tool that adds capabilities in support of the Agency processes. The lack of rigorous project management practices delayed efficient and broad use of the new tool and initially reduced its effectiveness. After emphasizing the processes and offering intensified training on the use of the capabilities of KPRO, there was a noticeable improvement in the project management environment. Project managers managed their projects more efficiently and increased their productivity.  

        The project manager should obtain a commitment to ensure that a dedicated systems engineer is assigned to the project full time during the requirements phase. A systems engineer was assigned to KPRO and attempted to gather KPRO requirements. The individual was spread too thin and pulled off too often to successfully complete his KPRO assignment. This resulted in about 3 months of development time lost while the developers pitched in and assisted the project manager with the requirements document.  

        Building a team with people who work well together and have the proper expertise can make or break a project. KPRO was very fortunate to have formed a small talented, cohesive team to work on the project. The original development team is still intact after more than 2 years. This has been a major factor in the successful implementation of this project management tool at KSC.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Acquire appropriate skill mix for data processing system development and testing

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Loss of original implementation personnel and management.
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Maintain configuration control, maintain identical configurations [for multiple site installations]

Title: ADEOS-II L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Use independent tools and analysis methods to verify system under test versus or in addition to tools which are part of the system under test
MissionDirectorate: Aeronautics Research, Science, Exploration Systems, Space Operations,

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Assess full budget impacts of launch delays and plan for technology refresh

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Provide a test/migration suite

Title: ADEOS-II NASA Ground Network (NGN) Development and Early Operations - Management of System Components
Lesson:
Engage Operational Component Management in Integration and Testing. 

     Integration of NGN's many components was a challenge both in terms of the management of the system-to-system interfaces and in the management of lines of authority and reporting for the various organizations involved. One of the methods used to manage this complexity was to charter a quarterly review panel consisting of “stake-holder” participants with management authority of the various NGN components. The actual ADEOS-II review panel consisted of stake-holder participants from NASA/GSFC Code 450 (ground station and CSOC responsibilities), NASA/GSFC Code 420 (EOS-G Program Office), NASA/GSFC Code 423 (DAACs and networking), NASA/GSFC Code 290 (networks), NOAA/NESDIS (real-time interfaces). Code 300 (quality assurance) also participated as a panel member, and NASA/JPL participated ex officio (SeaWinds management). 

     The ADEOS-II quarterly review panel proved to be very effective in identifying and working-off actions at the management level, and in directing actions to the working level as needed during the late phases of development and testing. The quarterly review panel was declared a success and disbanded after the successful ADEOS-II NGN Operations Readiness Review held in September 2002.

Title: ADEOS-II NASA Ground Network (NGN) Development and Early Operations -- System Components Re-Use
Lesson:
Re-Use of Existing Operational Components Lowers Cost and Reduces Risk. These are two of the obvious benefits gained by using operational components in the development and early operations of the NGN. The NGN was able to leverage the considerable investment by NASA in the multi-mission capabilities of the Alaska Synthetic Aperture Radar Faility, the Wallops Flight Facility, CSOC's Data Services Management Center, the EOSDIS Mission Support Network, the Physical Oceanography Distributed Active Archive Center, and the National Snow and Ice Data Center. Collectively these organizations provided data capture and Level 0 processing, domestic and international network connectivity, and archive and distribution capabilities. It was determined early in the design concept phase that it would be prohibitively expensive to develop all of the capabilities needed for the ADEOS-II NGN "from scratch." The re-use of existing management structures and systems was the obvious solution for a
    cost-effective solution to meet the requirements for NASA's support of ADEOS-II NGN requirements. During the design and early operations phase, all of the NGN component organizations provided the highest caliber of support to the project and program goals. The success of the NGN in meeting its requirements for support of the ADEOS-II mission is a positive lesson learned about the benefits of re-using and integrating operational components to meet ground system mission requirements.

Title: ADEOS-II NGN L0 Data Gap Introduction Problem
Lesson: Include adequate and useable Data Accounting capability, reports, and tools during requirements definition and system development.

Title: ADEOS-II NASA Ground Network (NGN) Development and Early Operations -- Central/Standard Autonomous File Server (CSAFS/SAFS) Lessons Learned
Lesson:
Match COTS tools to project requirements. Deciding to use a COTS product as the basis of system software design is potentially risky, but the potential benefits include quicker delivery, less cost, and more reliability in the final product. The following lessons were learned in the definition phase of the SAFS/CSAFS development. Use COTS products and re-use previously developed internal products. Create a prioritized list of desired COTS features. Talk with local experts having experience in similar areas. Conduct frequent peer and design reviews. Obtain demonstration versions of COTS products. Obtain customer references from vendors. Select a product appropriately sized for your application. Choose a product closely aligned with your project's requirements. Select a vendor whose size will permit a working relationship. Use vendor tutorials, documentation, and vendor contacts during COTS evaluation period.
    Test and prototype COTS products in the lab. The prototyping and test phase of the COTS evaluation allows problems to be identified as the system design to matures. These problems can be mitigated (often with the help and cooperation of the COTS vendor) well before the field-testing phase at which time it may be too costly or impossible to retrofit a solution. The following lessons were learned in the prototyping and test phase of the SAFS/CSAFS development. Prototype your systems hardware and software in a lab setting as similar to the field environment as possible; simulate how the product will work on various customer platforms; model the field operations; develop in stages with ongoing integration and testing Pass pertinent information on to your customers Accommodate your customers, where possible, by building in alternative options Don't approve all requests for additional options by customers or new projects that come on line. Select the best COTS components for product performance even if they are from multiple vendors.
